ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course offers an introduction to the Langlands program through the lens of derived algebraic geometry. The initial lectures (e.g. those on categorical harmonic analysis) are quite easy to follow, so that anyone with basic undergraduate training can understand the ideas. Over time, the course does get much more difficult as it begins to introduce material from more advanced category theory, topology, and algebraic geometry, but there is always a variety of material in each lecture so that you will never be completely lost.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It's tricky because this particular class probably won't be taught again. It has interesting content and got to survey a lot of different areas. Unlike most math classes, it has an idiosyncratic philosophy.
My only complaint is that I wish we did more concrete examples with derived algebraic geometry, but given the time constraints its understandable that we didn't.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! It has lots of neat ideas and almost no pain.
Excellent course for mathematicians interested in (complex) algebraic geometry and representation theory, and also reasonably accessible for physicists with a solid enough math background.
